oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Effect of mycorrhiza and plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria on rice in Northern India: results from 2005-2008
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Berset, Estelle
Srivastava, Rashmi
Mäder, Paul
Kaiser, Franziska
Adholeya, Alok
Fried, Padrout M.
Sharma, Anil K.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Crop husbandry
India
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Beneficial migroorganisms such as arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) and plant growth promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR) can ameliorate plant nutrition through an extended extra-radical hyphal network and by nutrient mobilisation. In the past, host specificity may not have been adequately considered when microbial inoculants were developed for different crops. In the Bio-fertilizer Network oft he Indo-Swiss Collaboration in Biotechnology (ISCB), AMF and PGPR are integrated as bio-inoculants in wheat-rice and wheat-black gram systems.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Berset, Estelle; Srivastava, Rashmi; Mäder, Paul; Kaiser, Franziska; Adholeya, Alok; Fried, Padrout M. and Sharma, Anil K. (2011) Effect of mycorrhiza and plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria on rice in Northern India: results from 2005-2008. In: estelle.berset@fibl.org (Ed.) Abstract Book of the ISCB International Symposium, p. 59.
